{{short description|Any kind of non-baryonic matter}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2016}} {{Refimprove|date=October 2016}}
In [[physics]], '''exotic matter''' is [[matter]] that somehow deviates from normal matter and has "exotic" properties. A broader definition of exotic matter is any kind of non-baryonic matter—that is not made of [[baryons]], the subatomic particles (such as [[protons]] and [[neutrons]]) of which ordinary matter is composed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.daviddarling.info/encyclopedia/E/exotic_matter.html|title=Exotic matter|publisher=[[daviddarling.info]]|accessdate=2015-06-24}}</ref> Exotic mass has been considered a colloquial term for matters such as [[dark matter]], [[negative mass]], or [[Mass#Tachyonic particles and imaginary (complex) mass|complex mass]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/4517897/nobel-prize-physics-2016/|title=Why 'Exotic Matter' Matters—and Won the Nobel Prize in Physics|website=Time|language=en|access-date=2018-03-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/4517897/nobel-prize-physics-2016/|title=Why 'Exotic Matter' Matters—and Won the Nobel Prize in Physics|website=Time|language=en|access-date=2018-03-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/scitech/science/356829/physicists-confirm-existence-of-new-exotic-matter/story/|title=Physicists confirm existence of new 'exotic' matter|work=GMA News Online|access-date=2018-03-27|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.space.com/8012-exotic-antimatter-created-earth.html|title=Exotic Antimatter Created on Earth|work=Space.com|access-date=2018-03-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nature.com/nature/supplements/insights/exoticmatter/index.html|title=Exotic matter : Insight : Nature|website=www.nature.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Anonymous|date=1998-08-03|title=Focus: Wormhole Construction: Proceed with Caution|url=https://physics.aps.org/story/v2/st7|journal=Physics|language=en-US|volume=2}}</ref>
==Types of exotic matter== There are several types of exotic matter:
* Hypothetical [[subatomic particle|particles]] and states of matter that have "exotic" [[physical property|physical properties]] that would violate known [[laws of physics]], such as a particle having a [[negative mass]]. * [[Hypothetical particle]]s and states of matter that have not yet been encountered, but whose properties would be within the realm of mainstream physics if found to exist. * Several particles whose existence has been experimentally confirmed that are conjectured to be [[exotic hadron]]s and within the [[Standard Model]]. * [[State of matter|States of matter]] that are not commonly encountered, such as [[Bose–Einstein condensate]]s, [[fermionic condensate]]s, [[quantum spin liquid]], [[string-net liquid]], [[supercritical fluid]], [[color-glass condensate]], [[quark–gluon plasma]], [[Rydberg matter]], [[Rydberg polaron]] and [[photonic matter]] but whose properties are entirely within the realm of mainstream physics. * States of matter that are poorly understood, such as [[Dark matter]] and [[Mirror matter]]. * Ordinary matter placed under [[high pressure]], which may result in dramatic changes in its physical or chemical properties. * [[Degenerate matter]] * [[Exotic atoms]]
== Negative mass == {{main article|Negative mass}}
Negative mass would possess some strange properties, such as accelerating in the direction opposite of applied [[force]]. Despite being inconsistent with the expected behavior of "normal" matter, negative mass is mathematically consistent and introduces no violation of [[conservation of momentum]] or [[conservation of energy|energy]]. It is used in certain speculative theories, such as on the construction of artificial [[wormhole]]s and the [[Alcubierre drive]]. The closest known real representative of such exotic matter is the region of pseudo-[[Pressure#Negative pressures|negative-pressure]] density produced by the [[Casimir effect]].
According to [[mass–energy equivalence]], mass <math>m </math> is in proportion to energy <math>E</math> and the coefficient of proportionality is <math>c^2 </math>. Actually, <math>m</math> is still equivalent to <math>E</math> although the coefficient is another constant <ref>{{cite journal |author1=Wang, Z.Y |author2=Wang P.Y |author3=Xu Y.R | date=2011 | title=Crucial experiment to resolve Abraham-Minkowski Controversy | journal=Optik | volume=122 | pages=1994–1996 | doi=10.1016/j.ijleo.2010.12.018 | issue= 22|bibcode = 2011Optik.122.1994W |arxiv=1103.3559 }}</ref> such as <math>-c^2 </math>.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Wang, Z.Y.|title=Modern Theory for Electromagnetic Metamaterials|journal=Plasmonics|date=2016|volume=11|pages=503–508|doi=10.1007/s11468-015-0071-7|issue=2}}</ref> In this case, it is unnecessary to introduce a [[negative energy]] because the mass can be negative although the energy is positive. That is to say,
:<math>E=-mc^2>0</math>
:<math>m= -\frac{E}{c^2}<0</math>
Under the circumstances，
:<math>dE=Fds=\frac{dp}{dt}ds=\frac{ds}{dt}dp=vdp=vd(mv)</math>
:<math>-c^2dm=vd(mv)</math>
:<math>-c^2(2m)dm=2mvd(mv)</math>
:<math>-c^2d(m^2)=d(m^2v^2)</math>
:<math>-m^2c^2=m^2v^2+C</math>
When <math>v=0</math>,
:<math>C=-m_0^2c^2</math>
Consequently,
:<math>-m^2c^2=m^2v^2-m_0^2c^2</math>
:<math>m={m_0\over \sqrt{1+\displaystyle{v^2\over c^2}}}</math>
where <math>m_0<0</math> is [[invariant mass]] and [[invariant energy]] equals <math>E_0=-m_0 c^2>0</math>. The squared mass is still positive and the particle can be stable.
Since <math>m= {m_0\over \sqrt{1+\displaystyle{v^2\over c^2}}}<0</math>,
:<math>p=mv= {m_0 v\over \sqrt{1+\displaystyle{v^2\over c^2}}}<0</math>
The [[negative momentum]] is applied to explain [[negative refraction]], [[inverse Doppler effect]] and [[reverse Cherenkov effect]] observed in a [[negative index metamaterial]]. The [[radiation pressure]] in the [[metamaterial]] is also negative<ref name="Veselago1">{{cite journal|last=Veselago|first=V. G.|title=The electrodynamics of substances with simultaneously negative values of permittivity and permeability|journal=Soviet Physics Uspekhi|year=1968|volume=10|issue=4|pages=509–514 |doi=10.1070/PU1968v010n04ABEH003699|bibcode = 1968SvPhU..10..509V }}</ref> because the force is defined as <math>F=\frac{dp}{dt}</math>. [[Pressure#Negative pressures|Negative pressure]] exists in [[dark energy]] too. Using these above equations, the [[energy-momentum relation]] should be
:<math>E^2 =- p^2c^2+ m_0^2 c^4</math>
Substituting the [[Planck-Einstein relation]] <math>E=\hbar\omega</math> and [[de Broglie]]'s <math>p=\hbar k</math>, we obtain the following [[dispersion relation]]
:<math>\omega^2 =- k^2c^2+ \omega_p^2</math>, <math>(E_0=\hbar\omega_p=-m_0c^2>0)</math>
of the wave consists of a stream of particles whose [[energy-momentum relation]] is <math>E^2 =- p^2c^2+ m_0^2 c^4</math>([[wave–particle duality]]) can be excited in a [[negative index metamaterial]].The velocity of such a particle is equal to
:<math>v=c\sqrt{\frac{E_0^2}{E^2}-1}=c\sqrt{\frac{\omega_p^2}{\omega^2}-1}</math>
and range is from zero to infinity
:<math>\frac{\omega_p^2}{\omega^2}<2</math>, <math>v<c</math>
:<math>\frac{\omega_p^2}{\omega^2}>2</math>, <math>v>c</math>
Moreover, the [[kinetic energy]] is also negative
:<math>E_k = E-E_0=-mc^2-(-m_0 c^2)=-{m_0c^2\over\sqrt{1+\displaystyle{v^2\over c^2}}} + m_0 c^2= m_0 c^2 (1-{1\over\sqrt{1+\displaystyle{v^2\over c^2}}})<0</math>, <math>(m_0<0)</math>
In fact, the [[negative kinetic energy]] exists in some models<ref>{{cite journal|author=Caldwell, R.R.|title=A phantom menace? Cosmological consequences of a dark energy component with super-negative equation of state|journal=Physics Letters B|volume=545|pages=23–29|date=2002|doi=10.1016/S0370-2693(02)02589-3|issue=1–2|arxiv = astro-ph/9908168 |bibcode = 2002PhLB..545...23C }}</ref> to describe [[dark energy]] ([[phantom energy]]) whose pressure is negative. In this way, the [[negative mass]] of exotic matter is now associated with [[negative momentum]], [[Pressure#Negative pressures|negative pressure]], negative kinetic energy and FTL ([[faster-than-light]]).
== Complex mass == {{Main article|Tachyon#Mass}}
A hypothetical particle with [[Complex number|complex]] rest mass would always travel faster than the [[speed of light]]. Such particles are called [[tachyon]]s. There is no confirmed existence of tachyons.
: <math>E = \frac{m\cdot c^2}{\sqrt{1 - \frac{\left|\mathbf{v}\right|^2}{c^2}}}</math>
If the rest mass <math>m</math> is complex this implies that the denominator is complex because the total energy is [[observable]] and thus must be [[real number|real]]. Therefore, the quantity under the square root must be negative, which can only happen if [[speed|''v'']] is greater than [[speed of light|''c'']]. As noted by [[Gregory Benford]] ''et al.,'' [[special relativity]] implies that tachyons, if they existed, could be used to communicate backwards in time<ref>{{cite journal|author1=G. A. Benford |author2=D. L. Book |author3=W. A. Newcomb |year=1970|title=The Tachyonic Antitelephone|journal=[[Physical Review D]]|volume=2 |page=263|doi=10.1103/PhysRevD.2.263|bibcode = 1970PhRvD...2..263B }}</ref> (see [[tachyonic antitelephone]]). Because [[time travel]] is considered to be non-physical, tachyons are believed by physicists either not to exist, or else to be incapable of interacting with normal matter.
In quantum field theory, complex mass would induce [[tachyon condensation]].
== Materials at high pressure == At high pressure, materials such as [[sodium chloride]] (NaCl) in the presence of an excess of either chlorine or sodium were transformed into compounds "forbidden" by classical chemistry, such as {{chem|Na|3|Cl}} and {{chem|Na|Cl|3}}. Quantum mechanical calculations predict the possibility of other compounds, such as {{chem|Na|Cl|7}}, {{chem|Na|3|Cl|2}} and {{chem|Na|2|Cl}}. The materials are thermodynamically stable at high pressures. Such compounds may exist in natural environments that exist at high pressure, such as the deep ocean or inside planetary cores. The materials have potentially useful properties. For instance, {{chem|Na|3|Cl}} is a two-dimensional metal, made of layers of pure sodium and salt that can conduct electricity. The salt layers act as insulators while the sodium layers act as conductors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gizmag.com/scientists-create-forbidden-compounds-table-salt/30520/ |title=Scientists turn table salt into forbidden compounds that violate textbook rules |publisher=Gizmag.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-21}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Zhang | first1 = W. | last2 = Oganov | first2 = A. R. | last3 = Goncharov | first3 = A. F. | last4 = Zhu | first4 = Q. | last5 = Boulfelfel | first5 = S. E. | last6 = Lyakhov | first6 = A. B. | last10 = Konôpková | first10 = Z. | doi = 10.1126/science.1244989 | title = Unexpected Stable Stoichiometries of Sodium Chlorides | journal = Science | volume = 342 | issue = 6165 | pages = 1502–1505 | year = 2013 | pmid = 24357316| pmc = |arxiv = 1310.7674 |bibcode = 2013Sci...342.1502Z }}</ref>

Its mission is to train young engineers and students about aerospace engineering and evaluate an advanced 3-axis magnetometer (SDTM) designed in [[Sweden]] by [http://www.astc.uu.se ASTC].{{cite web |url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/f-1.htm |title=F-1| publisher=Gunter's Space Page| author= Gunter Dirk Krebs | date= July 21, 2012 | accessdate= July 26, 2012}} F-1 was launched on 21 July 2012 and delivered to [[International Space Station]] (ISS) aboard [[Kounotori 3]] along with the [[Raiko]], [[We-Wish|We Wish]], [[Niwaka]] and [[TechEdSat]] cubesats. Then, on October 4, 2012, it was deployed into orbit from ISS using JEM Small Satellite Orbital Deployer (J-SSOD) which was attached to the [[Kibo (ISS module)|Kibo]] module's robotic arm.{{cite web |url=http://news.mynavi.jp/articles/2012/01/25/j-ssod/index.html |title= JAXA、宇宙ステーションから超小型衛星を放出できる装置をプレス公開| publisher=mynavi.jp| author= 大塚実 |language=Japanese | date= January 25, 2012 | accessdate= February 1, 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://iss.jaxa.jp/kibo/about/jssod/ |script-title=ja:「きぼう」日本実験棟からの小型衛星放出ミッション |language=Japanese |publisher=JAXA |date=October 5, 2012 |accessdate=December 1, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121113230512/http://iss.jaxa.jp/kibo/about/jssod/ |archivedate=November 13, 2012 |df= }} As of November 2, 2012, F-1 failed to confirm communication after the orbital deployment.{{cite web |url=http://www.southgatearc.org/news/november2012/attempt_to_recover_the_f1_amateur_radio_cubesat.htm#.ULtfkBBb_mE |title=Attempt to recover the F-1 Amateur Radio CubeSat |date=November 3, 2012 |accessdate=December 22, 2012}} [[File:CubeSats launched by ISS Expedition 33.jpg|thumb|220px|CubeSats deployed to orbit from the International Space Station on 4 October 2012 (from left: TechEdSat, F-1 and FITSAT-1).]] ==Hardware== [[File:F-1 mission patch 1 resize.jpg|thumb|F-1 mission patch]] * Structure: aluminium alloy T-6061 * Power supply: body-mounted solar cells, rechargeable Li-Polymer battery * PIC16 and PIC18 micro-controllers * Yaesu VX-3R handheld transceivers * C328 low-resolution camera * Temperature sensors * 3-axis magnetometer (ASTC) * [[2-meter band|2 meter band]] [[Dipole antenna|Dipole Antenna]] * [[70-centimeter band|70cm band]] [[Dipole antenna|Dipole Antenna]] ==Specifications== [[File:F-1 and other CubeSats at TKSC.jpg|thumb|F-1 and companion CubeSats at [[Tsukuba Space Center]], June 2012]] *Size: 10x10x10cm (1U cubesat) *Mass: 1 kg *Communication: 02 independent radios using amateur radio VHF & UHF bands, transmission speed 1200bit/s; AFSK & PWM Morse code modulation, KISS protocol *Payload: low resolution C328 camera (640×480 maximum resolution, 8 bit color) *Sensors: temperature sensors and 3-axis magnetometer * Targeted orbit lifetime: at least 3 months on orbit (depend on release altitude from the ISS) ==Communication Subsystem and Packet Format== [[File:Memorial pins on F-1 resize.JPG|thumb|Memorial pins on F-1 resize]] '''1. Backup UHF channel (only operational in daylight):''' *Frequency: 437.485 MHz *Modulation: Narrow FM *Power: about 0.2W RF output *Antenna: half-wave dipole * Beacon interval: 20 seconds duration, repeated every 90 seconds Pulse-Width-Modulation Morse code telemetry beacon {| class="wikitable" |- ! No1 !! Data !! Description !! Size (bits) !! Size (chars) |- | 1 || F-1’s callsign || "XV1VN" || || 5 |- | 2 || OBC1 reset count || Number of OBC1’s reset since the beginning || 8 || |- | 3 || Temperature 1 || °C (temperature inside F-1, OBC board) || 8 || 5 |- | 4 || Temperature 2 || °C (temperature outside F-1, Y- side) || 8 || |- | 5 || Checksum bit || 0 if summary of items #2 to #4 is even, 1 if it is odd || 1 || |- | || || || Total || 10 |} '''2. Main VHF channel (operational during night time but may be turned on in daylight later)''' *Frequency: 145.980 MHz *Modulation scheme: AFSK/FM *Power: 1.0W RF output *Antenna: half-wave dipole *Baud rate: 1200bit/s *Telemetry and interval: one burst of 3 telemetry packets in KISS format every 30 seconds (interval configurable) F-1’s KISS packet format {| class="wikitable" |- ! No !! Data !! Description !! Size (bit) |- | 1 || Date time || Date: dd/mm/y: 5/4/3=12 bits
Time: hh/mm/ss: 5/6/6=17 bits|| 29 |- | 2 || Battery voltage || Battery voltage multiplied by 100 (divide by 100 to get actual value) || 11 |- | 3 || Solar cells voltage || Solar cells voltage multiplied by 10 (divide by 10 to get actual value)|| 8 |- | 4 || Temperature 1 || °C (side 1, Y+)|| 8 |- | 5 || Temperature 2 || °C (side 2, Y-)|| 8 |- | 6 || Temperature 3 || °C (side 3, X-)|| 8 |- | 7 || Temperature 4 || °C (side 4, Z+)|| 8 |- | 8 || Temperature 5 || °C (side 5, Z-)|| 8 |- | 9 || Temperature 6 || °C (side 6, X+)|| 8 |- | 10 || Temperature 7 || °C (inside side 5, Z-)|| 8 |- | 11 || Temperature 8 || °C (inside, under VX-3R1)|| 8 |- | || || '''Total'''|| '''112 bits = 14 bytes''' |} Note: * F-1 periodically sends a burst of 3 telemetry packets with the same content, to avoid loss of packet * Time in UTC, 24 hours format * Year count starting from 2012 (2012 equals 0, 2013 equals 1 and so on…) * Battery voltage reading is accurate to 0.01V, values are multiplied by 100. Divide by 100 to get actual value. * Solar cells voltage reading is accurate to 0.1V, values are multiplied by 10. Divide by 10 to get actual value. * Temperature readings from sensors, will be added with 100 before transmission to ensure a positive number so please subtract 100 to get actual value * 112 bits, divide to 14 chunks of 8 bits, each chunk becomes one byte ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Portal|Spaceflight}} {{Commons category|F-1 (satellite)}} * [http://fspace.edu.vn/ Home page] * [http://www.facebook.com/groups/116436068290/ Facebook page] * [https://twitter.com/f1cubesat Twitter page] * [http://www.planet-techno-science.com/ciel-et-espace/f-1-un-micro-satellite-vietnamien-dans-lespace-fin-2011/ F1: un micro satellite vietnamien dans l'espace fin 2011] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120611112534/http://www.uk.amsat.org/5025 Vietnam Student CubeSat F-1] 24/2/2012 {{Orbital launches in 2012}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 2012]] [[Category:CubeSats]] [[Category:Student satellites]] [[Category:2012 in Vietnam]] [[Category:Artificial satellites orbiting Earth]] [[Category:Satellites of Vietnam]] [[Category:Satellites deployed from the International Space Station]]

Orbit |work=Heavens Above |date=September 13, 2015 |accessdate=September 13, 2015}} | orbit_rev_number = 66130 | apsis = gee | telescope_type = [[Ritchey–Chrétien telescope|Ritchey–Chrétien]] | telescope_diameter = {{convert|50|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} | telescope_focal_length= | telescope_area = | telescope_wavelength = 135–280 [[Nanometre|nm]] ([[Ultraviolet]]) | telescope_resolution = | programme = [[Small Explorer program]] | previous_mission = [[Reuven Ramaty High Energy Solar Spectroscopic Imager|RHESSI]] | next_mission = [[Aeronomy of Ice in the Mesosphere|AIM]] }} The '''Galaxy Evolution Explorer''' ('''GALEX''') is an [[orbit]]ing [[ultraviolet]] [[space telescope]] launched on April 28, 2003, and operated until early 2012. ==History== An airlaunched [[Pegasus (rocket)|Pegasus]] rocket placed the craft into a nearly circular orbit at an [[altitude]] of {{convert|697|km}} and an [[inclination]] to the [[Earth]]'s equator of 29 degrees. The [[First light (astronomy)|first observation]] was dedicated to the crew of the [[Space Shuttle Columbia]], being images in the [[constellation]] [[Hercules (astronomy)|Hercules]] taken on May 21, 2003. This region was selected because it had been directly overhead the shuttle at the time of its last contact with the [[Christopher C. Kraft Jr. Mission Control Center|NASA Mission Control Center]]. After its primary mission of 29 months, observation operations were extended to almost 9 years with NASA placing it into standby mode on 7 Feb 2012.[http://www.universetoday.com/93409/galex-mission-comes-to-an-end/ GALEX ends] NASA cut off financial support for operations of GALEX in early February 2011 as it was ranked lower than other projects which were seeking a limited supply of funding. The mission's life-cycle cost to NASA was $150.6 million. The [[California Institute of Technology]] negotiated to transfer control of GALEX and its associated ground control equipment to the California Institute of Technology in keeping with the [[Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980|Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act]]. Under this Act, excess research equipment owned by the US government can be transferred to educational institutions and [[Nonprofit organization|non-profit organizations]].{{cite news |author=Stephen Clark |title=NASA, Caltech mull over unique satellite donation |url=http://www.spaceflightnow.com/news/n1202/10galex/ |work=Spaceflight Now |date=10 February 2011 |accessdate=2010-02-17}} In May 2012, GALEX operations were transferred to Caltech.[http://phys.org/news/2012-05-nasa-ultraviolet-space-telescope-caltech.html Marcus Woo - NASA lends ultraviolet space telescope to Caltech (May 17, 2012) - Phys.org] On June 28, 2013 NASA decommissioned GALEX. It is expected that the spacecraft will remain in orbit for at least 65 years before it will re-enter the atmosphere.[http://www.galex.caltech.edu/newsroom/glx2013-03r.html NASA Decommissions Its Galaxy Hunter Spacecraft] ==Science mission== [[File:GALEX Field of View.jpg|thumb|left|GALEX field of view compared to a full Moon]] During its initial 29-month mission, which was extended, it made observations in [[ultraviolet]] wavelengths to measure the history of [[star]] formation in the [[universe]] 80 percent of the way back to the [[Big Bang]]. Since scientists believe the Universe to be about 13.8 billion years old,{{cite web |last= |first= |title=Cosmic Detectives |url=http://www.esa.int/Our_Activities/Space_Science/Cosmic_detectives |authorlink= |work= |publisher=The European Space Agency (ESA) |date=2013-04-02 |doi= |accessdate=2013-04-26}} the mission will study [[galaxy|galaxies]] and stars across about 10 billion years of cosmic history. The [[space observatory|spacecraft's]] mission is to observe hundreds of thousands of [[galaxy|galaxies]], with the goal of determining the distance of each galaxy from Earth and the rate of [[star formation]] in each galaxy. Near- and far-UV emissions as measured by GALEX can indicate the presence of young stars, but may also originate from old stellar populations (e.g. [[sdB stars]]). Partnering with the NASA [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] (JPL) on the mission are the [[California Institute of Technology]], [[Orbital Sciences Corporation]], [[University of California, Berkeley]], [[Yonsei University]], [[Johns Hopkins University]], [[Columbia University]], and [[Laboratoire d'Astrophysique de Marseille, France]]. The observatory participated in GOALS with Spitzer, Chandra, and Hubble.[https://arxiv.org/abs/0904.4498 GOALS: The Great Observatories All-Sky LIRG Survey] GOALS stands for ''Great Observatories All-sky LIRG Survey'', and [[Luminous Infrared Galaxies]] were studied at the multiple wavelengths allowed by the telescopes. ==Specifications== The telescope has a 50 cm diameter aperture primary, in a Richey-Chretien f/6 configuration.[http://www.astronautix.com/craft/galex.htm Encyclopedia Astronautica - GALEX] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080706050843/http://astronautix.com/craft/galex.htm |date=2008-07-06 }} It can see light wavelengths from 135 nanometers to 280 nm, with a field of view of 1.2 degrees wide (larger than a full moon). It has gallium-arsenide solar cells which supply nearly 300 watts to the spacecraft. ==Pre-launch images== {{Gallery|lines=3|width=150 |File:Galex PIA04264.jpg|GALEX at the pre-launch tests |File:GALEX Pegasus.jpg|GALEX being mated to a [[Pegasus XL]] Rocket |File:GALEXRollout.jpg|GALEX's [[Pegasus XL]] being attached to the [[Lockheed Martin|Lockheed]] [[Lockheed L-1011 TriStar|L-1011]] ''[[Stargazer (aircraft)|Stargazer]]'' |File:GALEXLaunch.jpg|The L-1011 ''Stargazer'' take-off with GALEX attached under-belly }} ==Examples of results== [[File:A-Mira-Full down sampled and cropped.jpg|thumb|699px|center|[[Mira]]'s bow shock and hydrogen gas tail in ultraviolet.]] {{-}} [[File:Ultraviolet image of the Cygnus Loop Nebula crop.jpg|thumb|center|420px|Ultraviolet view of [[Cygnus loop]]]] {{-}} ==See also== {{Portal|Spaceflight}} *[[GALEX Arecibo SDSS Survey]] *[[Arecibo Observatory]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|GALEX}} *[http://www.galex.caltech.edu GALEX website] by the [[California Institute of Technology]] *[http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/missions/galaxy-evolution-explorer-galex/ GALEX website] by the [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] *[http://galex.stsci.edu GALEX data archive] by the [[Space Telescope Science Institute|STScI]]{{\}}MAST *[http://galex.stsci.edu/GalexView/ GALEXView Search Tool] by the STScI{{\}}MAST *[http://wikisky.org/?object=M31&img_source=GALEX GALEX Ultraviolet Sky Survey] at [[Wikisky.org]] {{Explorer program}} {{Space observatories}} {{Jet Propulsion Laboratory}} {{Orbital launches in 2003}} {{Use American English|date=January 2014}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Galex}} [[Category:Artificial satellites orbiting Earth]] [[Category:Explorers program (NASA)]] [[Category:Space observatories]] [[Category:Ultraviolet telescopes]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 2003]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched by Pegasus rockets]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched by air-launched rockets]]

{{Redirect-distinguish|Inertial damper|Inertia damper}} {{original research|date=October 2018}} {{third-party|date=October 2018}} {{Unreferenced|date=March 2010}} '''Inertia negation''' is a hypothetical process causing physical objects with [[mass]] to act as if they were of lower mass or were massless. The effect is the opposite of adding [[ballast]]. No such process is known to exist in the real world: if current understanding of physics is correct, such a process would be impossible. There is currently no known material or technology that is able to eliminate or negate the effects of [[inertia]] that all objects with mass possess.
==Overview== According to [[Newton's first law]], "A body will continue in its state of rest or of uniform motion in a straight line, unless compelled to change that state by a net force." [[Inertia]] is the resistance against changes in the motion of an object. Objects within objects each possess their own inertia, and will collide with each other when the containing object is moved.
A device that would be capable of inertia negation is described as being capable of reducing the inertia of both the larger containing object, and of all contained objects within, so as to make changes in motion easier, and to reduce or prevent damage due to internal collisions. The inertia is not absorbed or redirected but simply ceases to have a physical effect.
[[Antimatter]], while being the opposite of [[matter]], has the same kind of inertia, with the forces oriented in the same direction, as normal matter. Thus, storing antimatter on board a vehicle made of matter would not achieve any kind of inertia negation.
== Inertia negation in fiction ==
Inertia negation is a commonplace technology in numerous [[science fiction]] series. It is used as an explanation as to why the crew of starships can withstand complex maneuvres or acceleration to [[Faster-than-light|FTL]] speeds.
Notable appearances include the [[Star Trek]] franchise, where inertial dampers protect the crew from the dangers of sudden accelerations. Another example is in the movie [[Alien (film)|Alien]].
In the fictional [[Mass Effect]] universe [[dark energy]] fields are used ubiquitously to modify mass of objects, e.g. of weapon projectiles to allow use of compact mass accelerators in order to achieve higher muzzle velocity, or even negate the mass of entire spaceships in order to enable FTL travel.
=== Inertial damper as shock absorber === Inertia negation is used to counter the effects of sudden acceleration that would impart structural stresses on star ships when suddenly accelerating to or decelerating with the [[impulse drive]], and which would cause passengers to be thrown against walls and crushed by the inertial effects of the vehicle suddenly accelerating or slowing.
Such a device does not need to negate or alter inertia – a similar effect can be achieved by creating a gravitational field opposing the acceleration of the vessel. Such technology, while still nonexistent at the present time and considered unlikely to be achieved in the foreseeable future, is by far more realistic than manipulating inertial mass.
== External links == * [http://memory-alpha.org/wiki/Inertial_damper Inertial damper] at Memory Alpha, the Star Trek wiki

[[File:Մարամեք աղբիւր.JPG|thumbnail|[[Maramec Spring]] in the [[Ozarks]], Missouri]] [[File:Fontaine de Vaucluse en crue.jpg|thumb|[[Fontaine de Vaucluse (spring)|Fontaine-de-Vaucluse]], [[karst]] spring of the [[Sorgues (river)|Sorgues]], characterised by an upward movement of water from the depth of over {{convert|315|m}}]] [[File:Vrulja kod Omiša.jpg|thumb|A submarine karst spring, called ''vrulja'', observed through sea surface rippling near [[Omiš]]]] [[File:Blautopf Quelle.jpg|thumb|[[Blautopf]], [[Swabian Alb]], Germany]] [[File:Tuhala Witches Well1-21-03-2013.jpg|thumbnail|"Witch's Well" karstic spring in [[Tuhala]], [[Estonia]]]] A '''karst spring'''<ref>Whittow, John (1984). ''Dictionary of Physical Geography''. London: Penguin, 1984, p. 291. {{ISBN|0-14-051094-X}}.</ref> is a [[Spring (hydrology)|spring]] that is part of a [[karst]] system. That includes the underground drainage of a much larger area, which means that karst springs often have a very large [[Discharge (hydrology)|discharge]]. Because of their often conical or bowl shape, such water sources are also known in German-speaking lands as a ''Topf'' ("pot") which is reflected in names such as [[Aachtopf]] (the source of the [[Radolfzeller Aach]]) or [[Blautopf]] (the source of the [[Blau (river)|Blau river]] in [[Blaubeuren]]).
Karst springs are usually the end of a [[cave]] system at the place where a [[river cave]] reaches the Earth's surface. Thus, it is often possible to enter the caves at a karst spring and explore them. Large karst springs are located in many parts of the world. The world's largest karst springs are believed to be in [[Papua New Guinea]], with others located in [[Mediterranean]] countries including [[Bosnia]], [[Turkey]], [[Slovenia]] and [[Italy]].<ref name="Ford2013">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=whgNDVXFiqYC&dq=tobio+spring+new+guinea&source=gbs_navlinks_s |title=Karst Hydrogeology and Geomorphology |first1=Derek |last1=Ford |first2=Paul D. |last2=Williams |year=2013 |publisher=John Wiley & Sons}}</ref>
==Types== {{Expand section|date=May 2012}} An '''[[estavelle]]''' or '''inversac''' is a ground orifice which, depending on weather conditions and season, can serve either as a sink or as a source of fresh water. It is a type of [[sinkhole]].<ref name="LaMoreaux2001">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.si/books?id=sjEoBmfUka0C&pg=PA57 |chapter=Geologic/Hydrogeologic Setting and Classification of Springs |page=57 |title=Springs and Bottled Waters of the World: Ancient History, Source, Occurrence, Quality and Use |first=Philip |last=Elmer LaMoreaux |year=2001 |publisher=Springer |isbn=978-3-540-61841-6}}</ref>
A '''Vauclusian spring''' is a spring that originates from a shaft or a cave system, with the water surging upwards under relatively high pressure. It is named after the [[Vaucluse|Fontaine de Vaucluse]] in southern France.<ref name="LaMoreaux2001" />
Submarine karst springs, also known as {{lang|hr|'''vruljas'''}}, occur worldwide, and are most numerous in shallow waters of the [[Mediterranean Sea]].<ref name="LaMoreaux2001" />
== Hydrological features == The main feature of karst springs results from the fact that water is rapidly transported by underground caverns. This means that there is minimal filtering of the water and little separation of different sediments. Groundwater emerges at the spring within a few days. Storms, snowmelt, and general seasonal changes in rainfall have a very noticeable and rapid effect on karst springs.
Many karst springs dry up during the driest part of the year and are thus known as '''intermittent springs'''. Still others are dry most of the year round and only flow after heavy rain. Sources that only flow during wet years are often known in German as ''Hungerbrunnen'' ("hunger springs"), the reason being that folklore sees a connection between the flow rate of a spring and poor yield in a wet year. It is however more of a culturally related [[superstition]]. Scientific studies on various ''Hungerbrunnen'' have not confirmed such a relationship. An example is the ''Hungerbrunnen'' in the parish of Heuchlingen near [[Gerstetten#The Hungerbrunnental|Gerstetten]].
The properties of karst springs make them unsuitable for the supply of [[drinking water]]. Their uneven flow rate does not support steady rates of consumption, especially in summer when there is lower discharge but higher demand. In addition, poor filtering and high [[Water hardness|hardness]] mean that the water quality is poor. For these reasons, karst springs are nowadays rarely used for drinking water.
==Cultural references== The French [[Realism (art movement)|Realist]] painter [[Gustave Courbet]] (1819-1877) painted a number of karst springs among many landscapes he depicted in the [[Jura (department)|Jura]] region of eastern France.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Fumey|first1=G.|title=Courbet, peintre du calcaire.|journal=Karstologia|date=2007|volume=50|pages=49-51|url=http://speleogenesis-info.isth.info/directory/karstbase/publication.php?id=3606|accessdate=2016-11-08}}</ref>

'''Libertad 1''' ({{lang-en|Freedom 1}}) is a single [[CubeSat]] built by the Space Program of the [[Sergio Arboleda University]] in [[Colombia]]. It was launched aboard a [[Dnepr (rocket)|Dnepr rocket]] on April 17, 2007 from the [[Baikonur Cosmodrome]], [[Kazakhstan]] and became the first Colombian satellite to orbit the Earth. It used a telemetric payload to keep it in communication with the University. It was expected to have a 50-day lifespan, however news reports two years after it was launched stated the satellite was still working and sending information, passing over Colombia twice a day.

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2012}} [[File:Michael 2018-10-10 1430Z.jpg|right|thumb|200px|[[Hurricane Michael]] making landfall in [[Florida]] near [[Mexico Beach, Florida|Mexico Beach]] as a strong [[Saffir–Simpson scale|Category 4]] hurricane on October 10, 2018]] The '''list of Florida hurricanes''' from 2000 to the present has been marked by several devastating [[North Atlantic hurricane]]s; as of 2017, 79 [[tropical cyclone|tropical]] or [[subtropical cyclone]]s have affected the [[U.S. state]] of [[Florida]]. Collectively, cyclones in Florida during the time period resulted in more than $123 billion in damage (2017 [[United States dollar|USD]]). Additionally, tropical cyclones in Florida were responsible for 145 direct fatalities and at least 92 indirect casualties during the period. Eight cyclones affected the state in both [[2004 Atlantic hurricane season|2004]] and [[2005 Atlantic hurricane season|2005]], which were the years with the most tropical cyclones affecting the state. Every year included at least one tropical cyclone affecting the state. During the 2004 season, more than one out of every five houses in the state received damage.<ref>{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|year=2005|title=Climate of September 2004|accessdate=March 14, 2008|url=http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/oa/climate/research/2004/sep/hazards.html}}</ref> After Wilma in 2005, it would be 11 years until [[Hurricane Hermine|another hurricane]] would strike the state, and 12 years until [[Hurricane Irma|another major hurricane]] would strike the state.
The strongest hurricane to hit the state during the time period was [[Hurricane Michael]], which was the strongest hurricane to strike the contiguous United States since [[Hurricane Katrina]]. Additionally, hurricanes [[Hurricane Charley|Charley]], [[Hurricane Ivan|Ivan]], [[Hurricane Jeanne|Jeanne]], [[Hurricane Dennis|Dennis]], [[Hurricane Wilma|Wilma]], [[Hurricane Irma|Irma]], and [[Hurricane Michael|Michael]] made [[landfall (meteorology)|landfall]] on the state as [[tropical cyclone scales|major hurricanes]]. {{clear-right}} {{horizontal TOC|align=center|nonum=yes|limit=2}}
==2000== [[Image:Debbyforecast.png|thumb|right|300px|A forecast map of [[Hurricane Debby (2000)|Hurricane Debby]] projecting its landfall in Florida]] {{See also|2000 Atlantic hurricane season}} *August 23, 2000 – The [[National Hurricane Center]] forecasts [[Hurricane Debby (2000)|Hurricane Debby]] to pass through the [[Florida Keys]] as a [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale|Category 2 hurricane]], with one computer model predicting a Category 4 hurricane in the area.<ref name="debbydisco15">{{cite web|author=Jack Beven|year=2000|title=Hurricane Debby Discussion Fifteen|publisher=NHC|accessdate=December 20, 2006|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2000/dis/NAL0700.015.html}}</ref> This results in officials declaring a mandatory evacuation for all non-residents in the keys, causing a significant loss of tourism revenue for [[Monroe County, Florida|Monroe County]]. Debby dissipates before hitting the area, though its remnants produce heavy rainfall across southern Florida.<ref name="debby00tcr">{{cite web|author=Richard J. Pasch |year=2000 |title=Hurricane Debby Tropical Cyclone Report |publisher=NHC |accessdate=December 20, 2006 |url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2000debby.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130502173304/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2000debby.html |archivedate=May 2, 2013 |df= }}</ref> *September 9, 2000 – Moisture from [[2000 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Depression Nine|Tropical Depression Nine]] produce light rainfall in the western [[Florida Panhandle]].<ref name="td900rain">{{cite web|author=David Roth|year=2005|title=Rainfall Summary for Tropical Depression Nine (2000)|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=December 20, 2006|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/td92000.html}}</ref> *September 18, 2000 – [[Hurricane Gordon (2000)|Tropical Storm Gordon]] makes landfall on [[Cedar Key, Florida|Cedar Key]], dropping up to 9.48 inches (240 mm) of rainfall in [[Mayo, Florida|Mayo]].{{Tropical Cyclone Point Maxima}} Hundreds of homes are damaged from floodwaters or fallen trees, and damage in the state amounts to at least $5.1 million (2000 USD, $7.2 million 2017 USD).<ref name="gordon00ncdc">{{cite web|author=NCDC|year=2000|title=Event Report for Hurricane Gordon|accessdate=December 20, 2006|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~389660|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519233327/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~389660|archivedate=May 19, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> A surfer drowns in rough seas near [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]].<ref name="gordon00tcr">{{cite web|author=Stacy Stewart |year=2000 |title=Hurricane Gordon Tropical Cyclone Report |publisher=NHC |accessdate=December 20, 2006 |url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2000gordon.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080920152242/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2000gordon.html |archivedate=September 20, 2008 |df= }}</ref> *September 22, 2000 – [[Tropical Storm Helene (2000)|Tropical Storm Helene]] hits near [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]], damaging hundreds of homes from floodwaters. Monetary damage totals over $1 million (2000 USD, $1.5 million 2017 USD).<ref name="helenencdc">{{Cite web|author=NCDC|year=2000|title=Event Report for Tropical Storm Helene|accessdate=December 20, 2006|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~389700|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519233401/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~389700|archivedate=May 19, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> *October 3, 2000 – The precursor disturbance to [[Tropical Storm Leslie (2000)|Tropical Storm Leslie]] produces 10—20 inches (255–510 mm) of rainfall across southeastern Florida, flooding about 93,000 houses. The flooding causes $950 million in damage (2000 USD, $1.4 billion 2017 USD),<ref name="lesliencdc">{{cite web|author=NCDC|year=2000|title=Event Report for Leslie|accessdate=December 20, 2006|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~389731|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519214957/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~389731|archivedate=May 19, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> along with three indirect deaths.<ref name="leslietcr">{{cite web|author1=James L. Franklin |author2=Daniel P. Brown |lastauthoramp=yes |year=2000 |title=Tropical Storm Leslie Tropical Cyclone Report |publisher=NHC |accessdate=December 20, 2006 |url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2000leslie.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101203041825/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2000leslie.html |archivedate=December 3, 2010 |df= }}</ref>
==2001== [[Image:Gabrielle damage (2001).jpg|right|thumb|Flood damage from [[Hurricane Gabrielle (2001)|Tropical Storm Gabrielle]]]] {{See also|2001 Atlantic hurricane season}} *June 12, 2001 – [[Tropical Storm Allison|Subtropical Depression Allison]] moves through [[Alabama]] and [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], with its outer [[rainband]]s producing up to 10.1 inches (357 mm) of rain at the [[Tallahassee Regional Airport]].<ref name="fldamallison">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center |year=2001 |title=Event Report for Florida (3) |accessdate=December 21, 2006 |url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~423575 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071222030820/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~423575 |archivedate=December 22, 2007 |df=mdy }}</ref> The rainfall destroys 10 homes and damages 599 others,<ref name="fladam">{{cite web|author=Gathana Parmenas |year=2001 |title=Detailed Damage Assessment Summary in Florida |accessdate=December 21, 2006 |url=http://www.tallytown.com/redcross/situation/allison-da.xls |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050516145603/http://www.tallytown.com/redcross/situation/allison-da.xls |archivedate=May 16, 2005 }}</ref> with monetary damage totaling $20 million (2001 USD, $27.3 million 2017 USD).<ref name="fldamallison"/> Eight people die in the state,<ref name="tcr">{{cite web|author=National Hurricane Center |year=2001 |title=Tropical Storm Allison Tropical Cyclone Report |accessdate=December 21, 2006 |url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2001allison.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080916074527/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2001allison.html |archivedate=September 16, 2008 |df=mdy }}</ref> five of which due to [[rip current]]s.<ref name="flrip2">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center |year=2001 |title=Event Report for Florida (2) |accessdate=December 21, 2006 |url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~423543 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071222030815/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~423543 |archivedate=December 22, 2007 |df=mdy }}</ref> *August 6, 2001 – After meandering for several days in the eastern [[Gulf of Mexico]], [[Tropical Storm Barry (2001)|Tropical Storm Barry]] makes landfall at [[Santa Rosa Beach, Florida|Santa Rosa Beach]], producing heavy rainfall across much of Florida which peaks at 11.7 inches (297 mm) in [[Stuart, Florida|Stuart]].<ref name="WPCMAX"/> The storm kills two in the state and leaves $1.5 million in damage (2001 USD, $2.05 million 2017 USD).<ref name="barry01tcr">{{cite web|author=Jack Beven|year=2001|title=Tropical Storm Barry Tropical Cyclone Report|publisher=NHC|accessdate=December 21, 2006|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2001barry.html}}</ref><ref name="barry01ncdc">{{cite web|author=NCDC|year=2001|title=Event Report for Tropical Storm Barry|accessdate=December 21, 2006|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~423938|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519233521/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~423938|archivedate=May 19, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> *September 14, 2001 – [[Hurricane Gabrielle (2001)|Tropical Storm Gabrielle]] hits [[Venice, Florida|Venice]], dropping moderate to heavy rainfall including a peak total of 15.1 inches (384 mm) in [[Parrish, Florida|Parrish]].<ref name="WPCMAX"/> The combination of flooding from rainfall and gusty winds causes $230 million in damage (2001 USD) and one direct death, and high waves from the storm indirectly kills a person in the [[Florida Keys]].<ref name="gabbytcr">{{cite web|author1=Miles B. Lawrence |author2=Eric S. Blake |lastauthoramp=yes |year=2001 |title=Hurricane Gabrielle Tropical Cyclone Report |accessdate=December 21, 2006 |publisher=NHC |url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2001gabrielle.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060707222809/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2001gabrielle.html |archivedate=July 7, 2006 |df= }}</ref> *November 5, 2001 – [[Hurricane Michelle]] passes to the south of the state, dropping up to 4.99 inches (127 mm) of rainfall.<ref name="WPCMAX"/> The hurricane spawns two tornadoes, resulting in minor damage.<ref name="michellencdc">{{cite web|author=NCDC|year=2001|title=Event Report for Hurricane Michelle|accessdate=December 21, 2006|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~424171|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519233532/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~424171|archivedate=May 19, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
==2002== [[Image:Edouard Recon (2002).jpg|right|thumb|200px|Tropical Storm Edouard seen by [[Hurricane Hunters]]]] {{See also|2002 Atlantic hurricane season}} *July 13, 2002 – The precursor disturbance to [[Tropical Storm Arthur (2002)|Tropical Storm Arthur]] moves across the [[Florida Panhandle]] and produces heavy amounts of precipitation peaking at 4.79 inches (122 mm) in two locations.<ref name="WPCMAX"/> *August 4, 2002 – High surf from [[Tropical Storm Bertha (2002)|Tropical Storm Bertha]] kills one person at [[Perdido Key State Recreation Area]].<ref name="bertha02tcr">{{cite web|author=Jack Beven|year=2002|title=Tropical Storm Bertha Tropical Cyclone Report|accessdate=December 21, 2006|publisher=NHC|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2002bertha.shtml}}</ref> *September 4, 2002 – [[Tropical Storm Edouard (2002)|Tropical Storm Edouard]] hits near [[Ormond Beach, Florida|Ormond Beach]] as a minimal tropical storm. While crossing the peninsula from east to west, the storm drops up to 7.64 inches (194 mm) of rain in [[DeSoto County, Florida|DeSoto City]], resulting in some flooding and minimal damage.<ref name="WPCMAX"/><ref name="edouard02tcr">{{cite web|author=Richard Pasch|year=2002|title=Tropical Storm Edouard Tropical Cyclone Report|publisher=NHC|accessdate=December 21, 2006|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2002edouard.shtml}}</ref> *September 14, 2002 – [[Tropical Storm Hanna (2002)|Tropical Storm Hanna]] strikes near the state border of [[Alabama]] and [[Mississippi]] and produces moderate precipitation across the state. Three people die in rip currents from the storm.<ref name="hanna02tcr">{{cite web|author1=James L. Franklin |author2=Jamie R. Rhome |lastauthoramp=yes|year=2002|title=Tropical Storm Hanna Tropical Cyclone Report|publisher=NHC|accessdate=December 21, 2006|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2002hanna.shtml}}</ref> *September 26, 2002 – [[Hurricane Isidore|Tropical Storm Isidore]] hits southern [[Louisiana]], though its large circulation drops rainfall across the state peaking at 9.1 inches (231 mm) in [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]].<ref name="isidoretcr">{{cite web|author=Lixion Avila|year=2002|title=Hurricane Isidore Tropical Cyclone Report|publisher=NHC|accessdate=December 21, 2006|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2002isidore.shtml}}</ref> Tornadoes spawned by the storm damage multiple mobile homes, with monetary damage across the state totaling over $11 million (2002 USD, $14.8 million 2017 USD).<ref name="isidorencdc">{{Cite web|author=NCDC|year=2002|title=Event Report for Tropical Storm Isidore|accessdate=December 21, 2006|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~458220|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519233546/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~458220|archivedate=May 19, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> *October 3, 2002 – [[Hurricane Lili]] makes landfall on southern [[Louisiana]], and drops 1.04 inches (26 mm) of rainfall in [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]].<ref name="lilitcr">{{cite web|author=Miles Lawrence|year=2002|title=Hurricane Lili Tropical Cyclone Report|publisher=NHC|accessdate=December 21, 2006|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2002lili.shtml}}</ref> *October 11, 2002 – [[Hurricane Kyle (2002)|Tropical Storm Kyle]] turns northward to the east of the state, producing up to 2.05 inches (52 mm) of precipitation in [[Fernandina Beach, Florida|Fernandina Beach]] and a light [[storm surge]].<ref name="kyle02tcr">{{cite web|author=Stacy Stewart |year=2002 |title=Hurricane Kyle Tropical Cyclone Report |accessdate=December 21, 2006 |publisher=NHC |url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2002kyle.shtml |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111022014734/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2002kyle.shtml |archivedate=October 22, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
==2003== [[Image:Tropical Storm Henri (2003).jpg|right|thumb|250px|[[Tropical Storm Henri (2003)|Tropical Storm Henri]] shortly before landfall]] {{See also|2003 Atlantic hurricane season}} *April 20, 2003 – Swells from [[Tropical Storm Ana (2003)|Tropical Storm Ana]] capsize a boat near [[Jupiter, Florida|Jupiter]], killing two of the four passengers aboard.<ref name="ana03ncdc">{{cite web|author=NCDC|year=2003|title=Event Report for Tropical Storm Ana|accessdate=December 30, 2006|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~494752|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519233551/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~494752|archivedate=May 19, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> *June 30, 2003 – [[Tropical Storm Bill (2003)|Tropical Storm Bill]] hits southern [[Louisiana]], producing over 7 inches (178 mm) of rainfall in portions of the western [[Florida Panhandle]].<ref name="bill03rain">{{cite web|author=David Roth|year=2005|title=Rainfall Summary for Tropical Storm Bill|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=December 30, 2006|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/bill2003.html}}</ref> At least 40 houses are damaged, totaling in over $1 million (2003 USD, $1.4 million 2017 USD) in damage,<ref name="bill03ncdc">{{cite web|author=NCDC|year=2003|title=Event Report for Tropical Storm Bill|accessdate=December 30, 2006|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~495031|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519233617/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~495031|archivedate=May 19, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> and rip currents from the storm kill two surfers in [[Panama City Beach, Florida|Panama City Beach]].<ref name="billtcr">{{cite web|author=Lixion Avila |year=2003 |title=Tropical Storm Bill Tropical Cyclone Report |publisher=National Hurricane Center |accessdate=December 30, 2006 |url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2003bill.shtml? |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081005072912/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2003bill.shtml |archivedate=October 5, 2008 |df= }}</ref> *July 2003 – A man dies after suffering a heart attack while swimming in high surf caused by [[Hurricane Claudette (2003)|Hurricane Claudette]].<ref name="claudette03tcr">{{cite web|author=Jack Beven |year=2003 |title=Hurricane Claudette Tropical Cyclone Report |publisher=National Hurricane Center |accessdate=December 30, 2006 |url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2003claudette.shtml? |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081022081621/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2003claudette.shtml |archivedate=October 22, 2008 |df= }}</ref> *July 25, 2003 – [[Tropical Depression Seven (2003)|Tropical Depression Seven]] forms to the east of the state and drops light precipitation.<ref name="td703rain">{{cite web|author=David Roth|year=2005|title=Rainfall Summary for Tropical Depression Seven (2003)|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=December 30, 2006|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/td72003.html}}</ref> *August 14, 2003 – The precursor disturbance to [[Hurricane Erika (2003)|Hurricane Erika]] produces heavy amounts of precipitation across the state.<ref name="erikaflorida">{{cite web|author=Nathan B. Collum |year=2003 |title=2003 Hurricane Season Summary |publisher=Florida Department of Emergency Services |accessdate=December 30, 2006 |url=http://www.irces.com/Emergency_Management_Division/2003_Hurricane_Season.pdf |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061017082929/http://www.irces.com/Emergency_Management_Division/2003_Hurricane_Season.pdf |archivedate=October 17, 2006 |df= }}</ref> *August 30, 2003 – Moisture from [[Tropical Storm Grace (2003)|Tropical Storm Grace]] drops about 1 inch (25 mm) of rain in the [[Florida Keys]] and over 3 inches (75 mm) in portions of northern Florida.<ref name="grace03rain">{{cite web|author=David Roth|year=2005|title=Rainfall Summary for Tropical Storm Grace|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=December 30, 2006|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/bill2003.html}}</ref> *September 6, 2003 – [[Tropical Storm Henri (2003)|Tropical Depression Henri]] hits [[Clearwater, Florida|Clearwater]], producing 9.09 inches (231 mm) in [[Hialeah, Florida|Hialeah]]<ref name="WPCMAX"/> which leads to minor flooding and damage; lightning caused by the storm injures a man in [[Lee County, Florida|Lee County]].<ref name="henri03tcr">{{cite web|author1=Daniel P. Brown |author2=Miles Lawrence |lastauthoramp=yes|year=2003|title=Tropical Storm Henri Tropical Cyclone Report|accessdate=December 30, 2006|publisher=NHC|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2003henri.shtml}}</ref> *September 13, 2003 – Rip currents produced by [[Hurricane Isabel]] kill a surfer in [[Nassau County, Florida|Nassau County]].<ref name="nws">{{cite web|author=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] |year=2004 |title=Hurricane Isabel Service Assessment |accessdate=December 30, 2006 |url=http://www.nws.noaa.gov/om/assessments/pdfs/isabel.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050504210810/http://www.nws.noaa.gov/om/assessments/pdfs/isabel.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=May 4, 2005 |format=PDF |df= }}</ref>
==2004== [[Image:Hurricane Charley damage.jpg|thumb|right|250px|President [[George W. Bush]], aboard [[Marine One]], surveys hurricane damage from [[Hurricane Charley]] at a [[mobile home]] park in [[Fort Myers, Florida|Fort Myers]]]] {{See also|2004 Atlantic hurricane season}} *August 12, 2004 – [[Tropical Storm Bonnie (2004)|Tropical Storm Bonnie]] moves ashore on [[St. Vincent Island, Florida|Saint Vincent Island]], producing light rainfall and minor damage along its path.<ref name="bonnie04tcr">{{cite web|author=Lixion Avila|year=2004|title=Tropical Storm Bonnie Tropical Cyclone Report|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=February 5, 2007|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2004bonnie.shtml}}</ref> *August 13, 2004 – [[Hurricane Charley]] passed over Upper Captiva at [[Cayo Costa State Park|Cayo Costa]] with winds of 150 mph (240 km/h) then made an unexpected 90° turn and headed straight for Pine Island making landfall at the center of Pine Island, devastating the cities of St. James, Pineland and Bokeelia. It then proceeded to the mainland portion of the state at [[Punta Gorda, Florida|Punta Gorda]], becoming the strongest hurricane to hit the United States since [[Hurricane Andrew]] in 1992. The winds damage or destroy thousands of homes, knock down tens of thousands of trees, and leave more than 2 million Floridians without power. Charley results in eight direct fatalities, 20 indirect casualties, and 792 reported injuries. Throughout the state, damage is estimated at $13.5 billion (2004 USD, $17.5 billion 2017 USD), at the time the second costliest hurricane in United States history; it has since dropped to sixth.<ref name="WPCMAX"/><ref name="charleytcr">{{cite web|author1=Richard J. Pasch |author2=Daniel P. Brown |author3=Eric S. Blake |last-author-amp=yes |year=2004|title=Hurricane Charley Tropical Cyclone Report|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=February 5, 2007|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2004charley.shtml}}</ref><ref name="charleyncdc">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=February 5, 2007|year=2004|title=Event Report for Hurricane Charley|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~534986|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519233633/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~534986|archivedate=May 19, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> *September 5, 2004 – [[Hurricane Frances]] strikes the southern end of [[Hutchinson Island South, Florida|Hutchinson Island]] as a slow-moving [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale|Category 2 hurricane]], producing heavy rainfall peaking at 15.84 inches (402 mm) at [[High Springs, Florida|High Springs]]. The hurricane damages 15,000 homes and 2,400 businesses in [[Palm Beach County, Florida|Palm Beach County]] alone, with damage across the state totaling $8.32 billion (2004 USD, $10.8 billion 2017 USD). Hurricane Frances kills five people directly in the state and is indirectly responsible for 32 deaths.<ref name="francestcr">{{cite web|author=John L. Beven II |year=2004 |title=Hurricane Frances Tropical Cyclone Report |publisher=National Hurricane Center |accessdate=February 5, 2007 |url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2004frances.shtml |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801211641/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2004frances.shtml |archivedate=August 1, 2013 |df= }}</ref> *September 16, 2004 – [[Hurricane Ivan]] strikes [[Orange Beach, Alabama]] as a major hurricane, with its large and powerful circulation producing peak wind gusts of 107 mph (173 km/h) in [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]]. The winds down more than 125,000 ft³ (3,540 m³) at a forest near Pensacola, while strong waves and a 10–15 foot (3—4.5 m) storm surge severely damages the [[Interstate 10 in Florida|Interstate 10]] bridge in Pensacola. Throughout the state damage totals $8 billion (2004 USD, $10.3 billion 2017 USD), and 14 people die in the state from the hurricane. The remnants of Ivan later cross over the southern portion of the state on September 21 after looping southward, and ultimately reform in the [[Gulf of Mexico]] on September 23.<ref name="ivantcr">{{cite web|author=Stacy R. Stewart |year=2004 |title=Hurricane Ivan Tropical Cyclone Report |publisher=National Hurricane Center |accessdate=February 5, 2007 |url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2004ivan.shtml |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070911070938/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2004ivan.shtml |archivedate=September 11, 2007 |df=mdy }}</ref> *September 13, 2004 – [[Hurricane Jeanne]] hits the southern portion of the state very near where Frances struck three weeks prior, producing moderate winds and rainfall reaching 11.97 inches (304 mm) at [[Kenansville, Florida|Kenansville]]. Jeanne produces hurricane-force winds across an area previously affected by one or two other hurricanes,<ref name="jeannetcr">{{cite web|author1=Miles B. Lawrence |author2=Hugh D. Cobb |lastauthoramp=yes |year=2004 |title=Hurricane Jeanne Tropical Cyclone Report |accessdate=February 5, 2007 |url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2004jeanne.shtml |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801211659/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2004jeanne.shtml |archivedate=August 1, 2013 |df= }}</ref> causing about $3.5 billion in damage (2004 USD, $4.5 billion 2017 USD).<ref>{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|year=2004|title=Event Report for Hurricane Jeanne|accessdate=October 2, 2007|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~529480|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519233641/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~529480|archivedate=May 19, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The passage of Hurricane Jeanne results in three deaths; two due to winds and one from flooding.<ref name="jeannetcr"/> *October 10, 2004 – [[Tropical Storm Matthew (2004)|Tropical Storm Matthew]] hits southern [[Louisiana]], with its outer [[rainband]]s producing light rainfall across the western portion of Florida.<ref name="matthew04rain">{{Cite web|author=David Roth|year=2005|title=Tropical Storm Matthew Rainfall Summary|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=February 5, 2007|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/matthew2004.html}}</ref>
==2005== [[Image:Beach front home damaged by hurricane dennis 2005.jpg|thumb|180px|right|A beachfront home in [[Navarre Beach, Florida]] largely destroyed by [[Hurricane Dennis]]]] {{See also|2005 Atlantic hurricane season}} *June 11, 2005 – [[Tropical Storm Arlene (2005)|Tropical Storm Arlene]] strikes just west of [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]], bringing moderate precipitation throughout the state<ref name="arlene05tcr">{{cite web|author1=Lixion A. Avila |author2=Daniel P. Brown |lastauthoramp=yes|year=2005|title=Tropical Storm Arlene Tropical Cyclone Report|publisher=NHC|accessdate=January 8, 2007|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL012005_Arlene}}|format=PDF}}</ref> and causing breaches on barrier islands on the [[Florida Panhandle]]. Damage totals over $3.5 million (2005 USD, $4.5 million 2017 USD),<ref name="arlene05ncdc">{{cite web|author=NCDC|year=2005|title=Event Report for Tropical Storm Arlene|accessdate=January 8, 2007|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~574218|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519233648/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~574218|archivedate=May 19, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> and one person dies in [[Miami Beach, Florida|Miami Beach]] from rip currents caused by the storm.<ref name="arlene05tcr"/> *July 6, 2005 – [[Hurricane Cindy (2005)|Hurricane Cindy]] hits south-central [[Louisiana]], with its large circulation resulting in moderate beach erosion and fallen trees along the western [[Florida Panhandle]]; damage is minor.<ref name="cindy05ncdc">{{Cite web|author=NCDC|year=2005|title=Event Report for Tropical Storm Cindy|accessdate=January 8, 2007|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~574329|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519233656/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~574329|archivedate=May 19, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> *July 10, 2005 – [[Hurricane Dennis]] makes landfall just west of [[Navarre Beach, Florida|Navarre Beach]] as a major hurricane, producing moderate rainfall and 9 tornadoes throughout the state. 2 people drown in the [[Gulf of Mexico]], and the hurricane was indirectly responsible for twelve other fatalities.<ref name="dennistcr">{{cite web|author=Jack Beven|year=2005|title=Hurricane Dennis Tropical Cyclone Report|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=February 4, 2007|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL042005_Dennis}}|format=PDF}}</ref> Damage in the state totals about $1.5 billion (2005 USD, $1.89 billion 2017 USD).<ref name="dennisncdc">{{cite web|author=NCDC|year=2005|title=Event Report for Hurricane Dennis|accessdate=February 4, 2007|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~574753|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519233701/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~574753|archivedate=May 19, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> *August 25, 2005 – [[Hurricane Katrina]], category 1 at the time, makes landfall near the [[Broward County, Florida|Broward]]/[[Miami-Dade County, Florida|Miami-Dade County]] border producing gusty winds and heavy rainfall peaking at 16.33 inches (415 mm) in [[Perrine, Florida|Perrine]]. Damage amounts to $523 million (2005 USD, $656 million 2017 USD) in the southern portion of the state, and twelve people die in southern Florida; three from drowning, three from falling trees, and six from indirect causes.<ref name="katrinancdc1">{{cite web|author=NCDC|year=2005|title=Event Report for Hurricane Katrina|accessdate=February 4, 2007|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~574879|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519233711/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~574879|archivedate=May 19, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Minor damage is reported along the [[Florida Panhandle]] from its landfall in [[Mississippi]].<ref name="katrinancdc2">{{cite web|author=NCDC|year=2005|title=Event Report for Hurricane Katrina (2)|accessdate=February 4, 2007|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~574885|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519233748/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~574885|archivedate=May 19, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> *September 12, 2005 – High surf from [[Hurricane Ophelia (2005)|Hurricane Ophelia]] kills a surfer in [[Palm Beach County, Florida|Palm Beach County]].<ref name="ophelia05">{{cite web|author=NCDC|year=2005|title=Event Report for Hurricane Ophelia|accessdate=February 4, 2007|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~574924|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519233828/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~574924|archivedate=May 19, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> *September 20, 2005 – [[Hurricane Rita]] passes south of the [[Florida Keys]], producing a 5-foot (1.5 m) storm surge which affects up to 200 residencies and severely injures a bicyclist.<ref name="ritatcr">{{cite web|author=NCDC|year=2005|title=Event Report for Hurricane Rita|accessdate=February 4, 2007|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~574929|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519233838/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~574929|archivedate=May 19, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> *October 5, 2005 – [[Tropical Storm Tammy (2005)|Tropical Storm Tammy]] hits near [[Atlantic Beach, Florida|Atlantic Beach]], resulting in moderate rainfall and light damage.<ref name="tammy05tcr">{{cite web|author=Stacy Stewart|year=2006|title=Tropical Storm Tammy Tropical Cyclone Report|accessdate=February 4, 2007|publisher=NHC|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL222005_Tammy}}|format=PDF}}</ref> *October 24, 2005 – [[Hurricane Wilma]] makes landfall near [[Cape Romano, Florida|Cape Romano]] as a major hurricane, producing hurricane-force winds and moderate precipitation across much of southern portion of the state. The winds of the hurricane leave 98% of South Florida without power. The passage of Wilma results in hundreds of damaged or destroyed homes, with damage reaching $20.6 billion (2005 USD, $25.8 billion 2017 USD), the fourth costliest tropical cyclone in United States history. Five people die in the state as a result of the hurricane.<ref name="wilmatcr">{{cite web|author1=Richard Pasch |author2=Eric Blake |author3=Hugh Cobb |author4=David Roberts |last-author-amp=yes |year=2006|title=Hurricane Wilma Tropical Cyclone Report|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=February 4, 2007|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL252005_Wilma}}|format=PDF}}</ref>
==2006== [[Image:alberto-flooding.jpg|thumb|right|Storm surge flooding from Tropical Storm Alberto at [[Horseshoe Beach, Florida]].]] {{See also|2006 Atlantic hurricane season}} *June 13, 2006 – [[Tropical Storm Alberto (2006)|Tropical Storm Alberto]] hits near [[Adam Beach, Florida|Adams Beach]], producing 4.51 inches (115 mm) of rainfall in [[Sarasota, Florida|Sarasota]] and a [[storm tide]] unofficially reaching 9 feet (2.7 m) in [[Dixie County, Florida|Dixie County]]. The passage of Alberto causes flood damage to dozens of homes.<ref name="alberto06tcr">{{cite web|author1=Lixion A. Avila |author2=Daniel P. Brown |lastauthoramp=yes|year=2006|title=Tropical Storm Alberto Tropical Cyclone Report|publisher=NHC|accessdate=December 21, 2006|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL012006_Alberto}}|format=PDF}}</ref> *August 30, 2006 – [[Hurricane Ernesto (2006)|Tropical Storm Ernesto]] strikes [[Plantation Key, Florida|Plantation Key]] and a short while later on the southwest Florida coastline. The storm spawns two tornadoes in the state, while moderate rainfall peaking at 8.72 inches (221 mm) in [[Golden Gate, Florida|South Golden Gate]] floods 13 houses in [[Palmdale, Florida|Palmdale]].<ref name="ernestotcr">{{cite web|author1=Richard D. Knabb |author2=Michelle Mainelli |lastauthoramp=yes|year=2006|title=Hurricane Ernesto Tropical Cyclone Report|publisher=NHC|accessdate=December 21, 2006|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL052006_Ernesto}}|format=PDF}}</ref>
==2007== {{See also|2007 Atlantic hurricane season}} *May 9, 2007 – [[Subtropical Storm Andrea (2007)|Subtropical Storm Andrea]] forms to the northeast of the state, and produces strong waves that cause severe beach erosion in some locations. Light rainfall, of up to 0.77 inches is reported in Jacksonville. Some coastal areas receive tropical storm force wind gusts.<ref name="sfs59">{{cite news|author1=Erika Pesantes, Sally Apgar |author2=Chrystian Tejedor |lastauthoramp=yes|date=May 9, 2007|title=Sweeping erosion hits Palm Beach County coast: Low-pressure system sucks swaths of sand; Jupiter feels brunt of it|publisher=South Florida Sun-Sentinel}}</ref> *June 2, 2007 – [[Tropical Storm Barry (2007)|Tropical Storm Barry]] makes landfall near [[Tampa Bay]] as a disorganized tropical cyclone, and drops moderate precipitation across the drought-ridden state that peaks at 6.99 inches (178 mm) in [[Palm Beach, Florida|Palm Beach]].<ref name="wpcpa14">{{Cite web|author=Fracasso|year=2007|title=Public Advisory Number 14 for Remnants of Barry|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=June 3, 2007|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/BARRY/BARRY_14.html}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> The rainfall causes slick roads, leading to two indirect traffic casualties. Damage in the state is minor.<ref>{{cite web|author=WFTV-9 |year=2007 |title=Barry Downgraded After Soaking Central Florida |accessdate=June 3, 2007 |url=http://www.wftv.com/news/13428614/detail.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070606113708/http://www.wftv.com/news/13428614/detail.html |archivedate=June 6, 2007 |df=mdy }}</ref> *August 23, 2007 – Rip currents from [[Hurricane Dean]] kill one person at [[Siesta Key, Florida|Siesta Key]].<ref name="TBO_usa_impact">{{cite web|author=Sarasota Herald-Tribune |publisher=The Tampa Tribune |date=August 23, 2007 |accessdate=August 25, 2007 |title=Lifeguards Rescue More Than 35 Off Siesta Key |url=http://www2.tbo.com/content/2007/aug/23/lifeguards-rescue-more-35-currents-siesta-key/?news-breaking |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071109104821/http://www2.tbo.com/content/2007/aug/23/lifeguards-rescue-more-35-currents-siesta-key/?news-breaking |archivedate=November 9, 2007 |df= }}</ref> *September 8, 2007 - Rough surf from [[Tropical Storm Gabrielle (2007)|Tropical Storm Gabrielle]] drowned one surfer and forced the rescue of 200 swimmers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clickorlando.com/news/14078956/detail.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-01-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716235621/http://www.clickorlando.com/news/14078956/detail.html |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |df= }}</ref> *September 13, 2007 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Humberto (2007)|Hurricane Humberto]] drop light rainfall on the western Florida Panhandle.<ref>{{cite web|author=David M. Roth|year=2007|title=Rainfall Summary for Hurricane Humberto (2007)|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=September 30, 2007|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/humberto2007.html}}</ref> [[Image:Noel2007 erosion.jpg|right|thumb|Beach erosion from Hurricane Noel]] *September 22, 2007 – [[Tropical Depression Ten (2007)|Tropical Depression Ten]] moves ashore near [[Fort Walton Beach, Florida|Fort Walton Beach]] and produces light to moderate rainfall,<ref name="pa2a">{{cite web|author=Avila|year=2007|title=Tropical Depression Ten Public Advisory Two-A|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=September 21, 2007|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2007/al10/al102007.public_a.002.shtml?}}</ref><ref name="wpc4a">{{cite web|author=Hedge |year=2007 |title=Tropical Depression Ten Public Advisory Four |publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center |accessdate=September 22, 2007 |url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/10/10_4.html }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> with its precursor system spawning a damaging tornado in [[Eustis, Florida|Eustis]].<ref>{{cite news|author=CBS.com |title=Florida Tornado Strikes 50 Homes |accessdate=September 21, 2007 |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/09/21/storm/main3285673.shtml |work=CBS News |date=September 21, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qXxCQDLk?url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/09/21/storm/main3285673.shtml |archivedate=June 17, 2010 |df=mdy }}</ref> *October 31, 2007 – The interaction between [[Hurricane Noel]] and a [[ridge (meteorology)|ridge]] to its north produces strong winds and high waves along the state's eastern coastline.<ref name="1031reut">{{cite news|author=Anthony Boadle|title=Tropical Storm Noel strengthens after hitting Cuba|publisher=Reuters Foundation|accessdate=October 31, 2007|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/homepageCrisis/idUKN31308688._CH_.242020071031 | date=October 31, 2007}}</ref> *December 13, 2007 – The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Olga (2007)|Tropical Storm Olga]] drop moderate precipitation in the state.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|year=2007|title=Rainfall Summary for Tropical Storm Olga|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=December 28, 2007|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/olga2007.html}}</ref>
==2008== {{See also|2008 Atlantic hurricane season}} *July 16, 2008 – The precursor to [[Tropical Storm Cristobal (2008)|Tropical Storm Cristobal]] drops moderate rainfall, causing minor street flooding and little damage.<ref>{{cite news|author=Bill Bair|date=July 18, 2008|title=System Likely to Deliver More Rain to Polk|work=The Ledger|accessdate=July 19, 2008|url=http://www.theledger.com/article/20080718/NEWS/807180436/1374&title=System_Likely_to_Deliver_More_Rain_to_Polk#}}</ref> *July 22, 2008 – Rip currents from [[Hurricane Dolly (2008)|Hurricane Dolly]] kill one person and injures four at beaches along the panhandle.<ref name="Florida death">{{cite news|author=Staff writer | url=http://www.wjhg.com/home/headlines/25818979.html|title=Beach Visitors Ignore Double Red Warning Flags|date=July 23, 2008|publisher=[[WJHG]]|accessdate=July 23, 2008}}</ref> *August 18–23, 2008 – [[Tropical Storm Fay (2008)|Tropical Storm Fay]] made a record four landfalls in Florida. Extreme flooding was reported in many counties in [[central Florida]] and the [[Florida panhandle]]. According to the [[National Hurricane Center]]'s [[Tropical Cyclone Report]] on Fay, five people were killed throughout the state.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Stacy R. Stewart |author2=John L. Beven II |lastauthoramp=yes|title=Tropical Storm Fay Tropical Cyclone Report|year=2009|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=February 26, 2009|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL062008_Fay}}}}</ref> *August 31 – September 1 – [[Hurricane Gustav]] brushed the Florida Keys before tracking into central Louisiana, producing six tornadoes, heavy rain up to {{convert|4.12|in|mm|abbr=on}}, and strong rip currents throughout the state. The outer rain bands produced three [[waterspouts]] in the Panhandle, each coming ashore near [[Valparaiso, Florida|Valparaiso]]. Four people drowned as a result of the rip currents in southern Florida.<ref>{{cite web|author1=John L. Beven II |author2=Todd B. Kimberlain |lastauthoramp=yes|publisher=National Hurricane Center|date=January 22, 2009|accessdate=May 13, 2009|title=Hurricane Gustav Tropical Cyclone Report|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL072008_Gustav}}}}</ref>{{Tropical Cyclone Rainfall in Florida}} *September 2, 2008 – Rip currents from [[Hurricane Hanna (2008)|Hurricane Hanna]] are reported along the Southeast U.S. Coast. A 14-year-old boy drowned at [[John U. Lloyd Beach State Park]] near [[Hollywood, Florida]] as a result of the rip currents brought up by the distant Hanna.<ref>{{cite web|title=Body Of 14-Year-Old Caught In Rip Current Is Found|year=2008|publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|accessdate=September 1, 2008|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2008/09/03/2353758.htm}}</ref> Two more deaths were reported off the coast of [[Fort Lauderdale, Florida]] as they drowned in the high seas.<ref name=WCPO>{{cite web|title=Hurricane Hanna Hits Bahamas, Threatens US |year=2008 |publisher=[[WCPO]] |accessdate=September 2, 2008 |url=http://www.wcpo.com/news/local/story.aspx?content_id=46b33106-0374-4773-ac4e-52461123f56f&rss=703 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080908145046/http://www.wcpo.com/news/local/story.aspx?content_id=46b33106-0374-4773-ac4e-52461123f56f&rss=703 |archivedate=September 8, 2008 |df= }}</ref>

16–18, 2009 – [[Tropical Storm Claudette (2009)|Tropical Storm Claudette]] hits [[Santa Rosa Island, Florida|Santa Rosa Island]], killing two people.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=National Climatic Data Center |year=2009 |accessdate=July 25, 2010 |title=Florida Event Report: Tropical Storm |url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~784001 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rUOz0SKr?url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~784001 |archivedate=July 25, 2010 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|publisher=National
